etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in James Franklin Warner (1802–1864). As adverb and adjective from Italian rapido rapid. As noun, partly from Italian rapido express train (1931; compare earlier rapidissimo (noun) in this sense; use as noun (perhaps short for treno rapido) of rapido), and partly from Spanish rápido express train

definitions: With rapidity, at a rapid tempo. Also as adjective: played or performed rapidly.
In Italy and (later) Spain: a fast intercity train, an express.
